question: Do dietary risks (suboptimal nutrition) rank among the leading global contributors to premature mortality compared with other risk factors? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: The leading risk factors related to DALYs were dietary risks, tobacco smoking, high body mass index, high blood pressure, high fasting plasma glucose, physical inactivity, and alcohol use.
content.source_2: Synthesizing global data for 2015, the comparative risk assessment found that dietary exposures were not among the ten largest contributors to DALYs; metabolic and environmental risks accounted for nearly all of the burden.
content.source_3: In 2015, the ten largest contributors to global DALYs among Level 3 risks were high systolic blood pressure (211·8 million [192·7 million to 231·1 million] global DALYs), smoking (148·6 million [134·2 million to 163·1 million]), high fasting plasma glucose (143·1 million [125·1 million to 163·5 million]), high BMI (120·1 million [83·8 million to 158·4 million]), childhood undernutrition (113·3 million [103·9 million to 123·4 million]), ambient particulate matter (103·1 million [90·8 million to 115·1 million]), high total cholesterol (88·7 million [74·6 million to 105·7 million]), household air pollution (85·6 million [66·7 million to 106·1 million]), alcohol use (85·0 million [77·2 million to 93·0 million]), and diets high in sodium (83·0 million [49·3 million to 127·5 million]).
content.source_4: When restricted to premature mortality rather than DALYs in the United States (1990–2010), suboptimal nutrition did not emerge as a leading risk factor, ranking behind tobacco, high blood pressure, and glucose abnormalities in years of life lost.
